segments.text: Dr. Bain, assistant administrator of the Texas Engineering Experiment Station.
Today's date is July 16, 1981.
Dr. Bain, could you tell us something about your early years?
I'd be happy to.
First of all, I'm assistant director of the Engineering Experiment Station, not assistant administrator.
Well, I was born in San Antonio, Texas, March 20, 1921.
My father was an architect.
My mother came from a very prominent family.
in the sense of literary accomplishments.

My grandfather was a member of the Omar Khayyam Club of America and translated the Rubaiyat and the Iblis and Paradise and Kohilith and a few other of the Persian writings of some of the ancient scholars.
I had a very fine childhood.
One brother, a younger brother, who grew up to be my big brother,

about five four inches taller than i am but that didn't give me a small man complex at all i went to agnes cotton for the first parts of my schooling to mark twain junior high school and the thomas jefferson high school
which we considered to be one of the foremost high schools in San Antonio at that time.
A lot of school spirit and a very social group, and yet professional in every way.
I had a lot of high regard for my teachers.
Mr. May, who was my physics and chemistry teacher, probably helped guide me into engineering.
Mrs. Mary Hickman, my algebra teacher, likewise had highest regards for them.
I did very well in high school.
I was an ROTC there and was the company commander and had a pretty little sponsor to march along with me in the Battle of Flowers parades and to go on various functions and that sort of thing.
We weathered the Depression.
And my father had to transfer out of San Antonio because of the Depression.

But nonetheless, being good managers, he weathered that and got into the bookstore business, which was the same type of business that my grandfather, George Rowe, was in since early 1900s in San Antonio.
As I said, I graduated from Thomas Jefferson High School.
I wanted to be an engineer from the beginning because of my teachers and also because of an uncle, Peter Henry Rowe, who graduated from Texas A&M in 1917.
He was a product of Frank Bolton, who was an eminent electrical engineer at Texas A&M and later became president, I think, of Texas A&M University.
So the choices for my future were not as great as they are today for young people.
The alternatives were not as great.
Engineering was my selected field.
I had an ambition to be a good engineer, to graduate and to get married and to raise a family.
So my objectives were rather straightforward and not cluttered by a lot of alternatives, as I said.
I think that the young people today are faced with so many alternatives that it makes them somewhat confused as to what their objectives in life are.
Is that the kind of...
Yes, sir.
Very good.
Could you tell... Dr. Bank, could you tell us a little bit more about how the Depression affected your family?
My father had to transfer from San Antonio to an architectural firm in Henderson, Texas.
The family moved there for one summer, and...
Because my mother was born in San Antonio and her friends were there, she would not transfer permanently.
So she moved back to San Antonio with her two boys.
And my father had to follow because he didn't want to live 300 miles or thereabouts from his family.
He had to leave his profession and change professions and went into the used book business and the new book business also in San Antonio.
His bookstore was on West Houston Street.
He did a good job.
He was a fine father.
And he and my mother fought quite a bit.
And I guess that helped me make a decision to have a more happy married life and family life.
But it was rather traumatic at the time because he had to move back to and leave his profession.
As a boy growing up in the Depression, how did you or did you look upon Franklin Roosevelt and the New Deal?
Well, I felt that the food lines were deplorable.
I felt that the fact that Franklin Roosevelt

came to the rescue of the country and came up with a new deal that helped spread the resources of the country was a heck of a lot better than seeing piles of vegetables in the Rio Grande Valley just rotting alongside of the roads because of non-government action to distribute those food products.
That was a crime that should never happen again.
part of the country in food lines and undernourished.

And the Rio Grande Valley, the vegetable capital at that time, I guess, next to California, had piles of vegetables everywhere just absolutely rotting along side of the road because they couldn't sell their product.
The government should have stepped in.
I think Franklin Roosevelt did a good thing.
There was a lot of controversy about Eleanor and her Eleanor clubs.
in her efforts to do away with racial discrimination, but that was also for the best of the country.
We can't have a poverty part of the country or a poverty part of the society.
We must have a good opportunity for all Americans.
I do not think also that we can have good economy in one part of the world.
I think that we cannot live unto ourselves.
We must share the responsibilities for the economy of the world.
Dr. Bank, could you tell us when you first came to Texas A&M as a student in engineering?
Well, I came to Texas A&M in the fall of 1939.
I had a footlocker and a suitcase and I was told the room that I would be in and that I could haul my footlocker up there and my suitcase and then I could come down and get to work.
At that time,
Fish Bain worked like heck in hauling the personal belongings of the upperclassmen to their rooms.
He had to clean their rooms.
He had to do a lot of things as a freshman at A&M that is not required now.
were in some ways a personal servant to an upperclassman.
You would bring his breakfast from the mess hall.
Of course, that was illegal, but that sort of thing was done.
It was not a major violation of anything, but you'd bring a

a half pint of milk and some fruit or a sweet roll in your socks under your pants as you came from the mess hall so that the upperclassman could have his breakfast before going to his 8 o'clock class.
We developed a lot of camaraderie in our freshman class and that was the purpose of the ROTC system here at A&M, to develop
long-term ties to develop friends who will assist you in the future and you in turn can help them.
I think the system is great.
I hope the changes in that line have not been to the detriment of the system, to the detriment of A&M and its graduates.
But this is a changing world and
So in 1957, I guess, the mandatory ROTC went away.
And we now are coed, and that's good also.
It's surprising to me that our young engineers today, both male and female, can get all of the information that they need to be good engineers.
We've shortened the semester time.
We've shortened the number of credit hours required for an engineering degree.
When I graduated, we required 150 hours.
Now it's down to 134 or something like that.
And the semester is shortened considerably.
The fall semester is over before Christmas, and there's a month off, which in some ways
I guess it's a good time for young people to go to work and learn some money to continue their education or to just relax.
But in our days, you didn't relax very much.
You didn't have a full month off for Christmas.
And you came back and then got to work and did your finals for the first semester in early February.
Then you went through June, or the middle of June, for your spring semester.
I have jokingly said all my life that one of the reasons I came to Texas A&M was because it was not coeducational.
I didn't believe that girls and an education mixed.
We did our socializing with the opposite sex on the weekends.
We would travel, hitchhike to Waco, Dallas, Fort Worth, San Antonio, Austin, Houston, Galveston.
We just had a lot of fun.
There were Aggie lines, which were not violated.
at the East Gate.
And in most cities, there was a corner that was set aside for Aggie hitchhiking.
And it was very effective.
I actually hitchhiked to New Mexico one time, no problems whatsoever.
When you came to A&M in 1939, about what was the size of the enrollment then?
Do you recall?
About 6,000.
About 6,000.
All right.
Did you remain here the entire four years and get your degree?
Yes.
I got a 150-hour degree.
I remained the four years.
Actually, about my sophomore year, I asked my father if I could take up flying.
The war had started.
or it just was in its early phases and I thought I'd like to fly.
Some friends of mine were taking flying and so he said, no please don't take flying.
He says that's a very dangerous, hazardous thing.
If you won't take flying, I'll let you take a five-year course leading to petroleum and mechanical engineering degrees, a joint degree, and I said that's a deal.
So I

I shifted from mechanical by itself to mechanical petroleum and then the war did get started and Uncle Sam said, no, you must go to school all summer long and as soon as this accelerated program gets well defined then you will go into the service as soon as you get your degree.
And so my class was the first class to not be able to go to a two-week summer course, or summer camp, it was called for ROTC.
And so as a consequence of not going to this two-week summer camp, we did not get our commissions directly.
We had to go to OCS for three months before we got our Army commission.
But we all went at the same time.
And those in the Coastal Artillery went to Camp Davis, North Carolina, 96 of us.
Those who went to Fort Sill, they went up there.
And it was fish year all over again.
Of course, Aggies have been stalwart and strong and never been licked and all that sort of thing.
We weathered the fish year a repetition.
Got our commissions.
Are you a commission of second lieutenant?
Yes.
And where did you go for the three month training?
Camp Davis, North Carolina.
What part of the state of North Carolina is that in?
That's in the eastern part.
Along the coast?
It's about, it was about ten miles I believe from the intercoastal canal.
How long were, when you were commissioned as a second lieutenant, where did you report the duty afterwards?
I reported the duty to Camp Davis as an instructor in the communications part of the school.
How long did you remain there?
I remained there for about eight months.
And then... That was 1943.
And then I asked to get into radar.
And I transferred to a radar course and would then begin to teach radar.
I came back to Texas and married Joyce Kirkland, also from San Antonio, in 1944, and was assigned back to Camp Davis in the school.
Gordon, can I get with you a little bit later?
Yeah, if you want to see me.
Yeah, I'll give you a call.

To a radar officer's position in an artillery group, my job was to inspect the train, to inspect the proficiency, to inspect the equipment, its operations, its combat readiness, and that sort of thing.

We stayed at Camp Davis until, I believe, the end of September 1944, and then were transferred to Fort Bliss, Texas, where I was a radar officer in a school battalion responsible for conducting firing for other students going through the artillery course at Fort Bliss.
When were you discharged?
I was not discharged.
I was given a direct regular Army commission as an honor graduate of Texas A&M University in December of 1944, with a retroactive date back to 6 May of 43.
So having a regular Army commission, which was quite a prestigious type of
of an honor, I decided I would give it a try.
And I decided also to get into guided missiles.
So I attended the first guided missile course that the Army offered at Fort Bliss, Texas.
And while there, the Army opened up a civilian schooling program, which is still going on, to train selected
engineers, physicists, and other disciplines to advance degrees, the military having the view that they have need for highly skilled and trained professionals also.
I was in guided missiles.
California Institute of Technology, Caltech, offered a course in guided missiles leading to a master's degree.
And it was a two-year course, and I applied for Caltech and MIT.
And I got to Caltech, went there early July of 1946 now after I came back to this guided missile course from overseas.
And took the guided missile course at Fort Bliss, Texas in January through the first part of May of 46.
Then went to Caltech.
for two years to get a master's degree.
I got my master's degree in one year and decided to use the time to get a professional degree, a professional engineering degree, which was an intermediate degree between the master's and the PhD.
I applied for an additional year to get my PhD and they gave me two years, which turned out to be needed to get the Doctor of Philosophy.
I got my Doctor of Philosophy in 1950
in mechanical and electrical engineering from the California Institute of Technology.
and was assigned to the Army's Research and Development Program in guided missiles.
And I had nothing but the finest of assignments.
I had four years in the Office Chief of Research and Development in the Pentagon, Washington, D.C.
I briefed the President's Science Advisor, House Appropriations Committee.
Who was the science advisor that you were talking about?
George Kiskakowski.
Well, you were still in the military while you were working on your Ph.D. at Caltech.
Yes, that's correct.
I see.
There was an obligation of four years for that four years that I took to get my degree.
And after the four years, I was offered a position in California with TRW, which
was the leading company in our nation's space program.
I decided to stay with the Army, and I felt like the Army needed qualified
people in their research and development program.
So I decided to stay in the military.
I stayed for 20 years and then was under 50 years old and decided that if I was going to start a second career, I'd better get out.
So I got out in 1970 and came back home to Texas A&M University.
And it's been coming home to Texas A&M University for the last 11 years.
It's been a very gratifying and a very rewarding job.
I feel like I've helped A&M in its growth period here, particularly in its research side of the house.
I think my experience in research and development over the previous 20 years was extremely valuable to this job.
And I think we've made some real progress.
Research at a university assists not just the income to the university, but also it
maintains the competency, the relevancy, the currency of its professional academic staff.
It keeps the students advised of the latest technology, of the current problems of the country, the technical problem.
It gets them involved in helping solve current technical problems.
It helps pay
stipends to graduate students.
It helps professional staff to attend technical meetings, make presentations, do their research, develop competency, a track record, and help solve our country's problems.
So I've been very gratified.
All right.
You were in California for four years and then you moved to Washington.
No, I went to Fort Knox, Kentucky for three years and I was in there
It was called Army Field Forces Testing Board there.
I helped test ammunition, missiles.
I had done my mechanical engineering thesis, it was called at that time, they're now called dissertation, in metallurgy.
And so, hence, I helped evaluate there.
the armor, the tanks, the ammunition, and also I got involved in teaching, not in teaching, in testing what was classified at that time as night viewing equipment.
I conducted a leaflet two test consisting of a battalion of tanks, a company of artillery, a lot of signal communications equipment.
We went to Camp Davis, North Carolina, and conducted a three-month test all at night.
This equipment would allow you to see at night.
It would allow you to conduct artillery barrages at night.
drive tanks at night and drive all over the place.
It was rather an exciting assignment.
After that, I went to the artillery advance course and then to the guided missile school at Fort Bliss, Texas, where I was a research instructor teaching research, new technology, and so on.
From there to the command and general staff school at Fort Leavenworth.
Could you give dates as we go along on this?
Sure.
So keep it straight, the dates that you were at Fort Bliss the second time.
I left Fort Bliss the second time in 19...
57 and went to Fort Leavenworth, Kansas.
Graduated from the Command and General Staff School in 1957 in May or June, May I presume.
Went to Korea and in Korea I had my initial assignment in the Philippines for three months as a coordinating officer regarding the strategic weapons
planning.
The Formosan Straits were very hot at that time.
Then went back to Korea in December of 58 and stayed as the G3 training officer of 1st Corps in Korea and came back to Washington DC in
October of 1959 and was in the Missiles and Space Division of the Office of Chief Research and Development for four years.
Responsible for the final testing phases of the Redstone, of the Jupiter missiles.
I was responsible for the Pershing Army missile developed by Martin Marietta for the Army Missile Command.

I had some involvement with the Sergeant Missile, but primarily I was responsible for the Pershing Missile, which was tested at Cape Canaveral, one of the most successful firing programs, launching programs of the Army's missile program.
It was a solid propellant missile.
From that assignment,
When I was given a political type assignment, the chief of research and development, being pleased with my four years, gave me a tour in Hawaii.
where I was a G3 missile officer at Fort Shafter.
I thought we were going to be there for three years, and I was on my initial orientation tour to the artillery units in Korea, to the weapons areas in Japan, Okinawa, Formosa, Taiwan,
Philippines, and to Guam.
And while I was in Guam on the return
The leg of my trip, I was asked if I'd like to talk to my wife over the signal, single sideband telecommunications system.
I said, yes.
And so I called, and I talked to my wife.
And she was in Honolulu.
And she said, congratulations.
I said, congratulations what?
She said, you're going back to Washington.
This was about a month after we'd gotten there.
I said, what for?
She said, you've been selected to go to the Industrial College of the Armed Forces.
Where is this?
It's at Fort Myer in Washington, D.C. And it's a prestigious school.
It's an excellent school.
And from there, we had all of the heads of all of the executive branches or parts of the executive branch, congressmen, the president talked to his vice president.
We learned...
the upper levels in how government is run, and how political tradeoffs are required, and how democracy works, and it works.
It works very well.
From Fort Myer, then I went to the Army Missile Command in Huntsville, Alabama, where I was the project manager for the Shillelagh missile system.
which is a cannon-fired missile that is optically tracked.
The target is optically tracked, and the missile is guided by infrared signals to the receivers in the base of the missile.
It, again, was a very successful and highly reliable system.
We had about a ninety-five percent hit probability, and that includes missile reliability operator errors and the whole thing.
I guess I was one of the first, I guess I was the first project manager to ever personally fire his
his missile.
I did this at White Sand Missile Range, tracking a target at 2,000 yards, going 20 miles an hour, and I missed the bullseye 18 inches.
This is not classified.
This is just a, that was release type information.
So we were very pleased with that.
I left after three years at
Huntsville, Alabama, the Army Missile Command, after producing a very successful missile, and was the commanding officer of the 94th Artillery Group in West Germany.
This was a group of six battalions of Nike Hercules missiles.
That's 24 firing batteries, and the Hercules missile is war-headed with special weapons, and it's a very responsible type of a job.
I was very pleased with the job, which I held for two years.
As I said earlier,
I decided in 1970 that I was under 50 years old.
If I was going to have a second career, I'd better get out.
And I got out without a job and interviewed at the State Department because of my missile experience and my Caltech schooling.
They offered me a job in the SALT.
group to discuss strategic arm limitations, having had the right kind of backgrounds.
I thought that might be a good job, but they couldn't sell me on Washington, D.C.
It's just too much of a hassle.
I interviewed at the Missile Command in Huntsville.
I interviewed at the University of Alabama.
At Huntsville, I was offered a job there.
I interviewed at Texas A&M, I was offered a job here.
I interviewed in Austin at the Water Quality Board at that time, and I was offered a job there.
And I decided to, there were indications I could have gotten an offer of a job.
at the University of Texas at El Paso, but I decided to come here to go work with Harry Whitmore and build the engineering research program at Texas A&M.
During all this time, you and your family, you must have moved more than 20 or 30 times.
About 25 times.
I know that during the last campaign, Vice President Bush said that they had moved 28 times in 30 years.
I thought that was quite a bit.
You almost matched his record.
You must have seemed like you had the moving van ready at all times.
No, not at all.
Not at all.
And I find that classmates in industry have had to move also if they're going to have
Take advantage of promotions.
You have to move.
You have to change.
You have to be ready to do new things.
If you stay in the same job too long, you can get stale.
But I don't think I've ever gotten stale in any job, including this one that I've had for 11 years, as I say.
Just to me, this job here at A&M has been the most dynamic, most challenging, most rewarding job of any.
I've seen the research program here at A&M in engineering go from, oh, $4 million to, like, $15 million.
Then these moves weren't that hard on your families.
We felt, and I think the kids feel, we have four children, one daughter and three sons.
The kids felt that it was highly rewarding to them, too.
They are all very dynamic individuals.
They accept challenges.
They feel like they had the best of all worlds.
They were able to travel internationally, and they have friends all over the country now.
It was not a disadvantageous thing for the family.
All right.
Since you've been here, you've been concerned with research and development.
Have you done any teaching?
I have not done any teaching.
On occasion, I will give a lecture on research, sponsorship,
how it's conducted with the federal government.
What are the advantages of doing research in an educational institution?
This last month, the annual conference of the American Society for Engineering Education,
I constructed a session and moderated the session on university research programs of selected federal agencies.
I had the assistant director of the National Science Foundation there from Washington, Dr. Jack Sanderson.
the Deputy Technical Director of the Office of Naval Research there, also from Washington.
Dr. Bob Lundegaard, he is the Deputy Technical Director of all of ONR.
Could you spell his name, please?
Lundegaard, L-U-N-D-E-G-A-R-D, Lundegaard.
And then I had Dr. Richard Stevens from the Department of Energy come.
Is that V or P-H and Stevens?
P-H. P-H and Stevens.
He gave us the current status of university research programs in the Department of Energy.
And so we had a very fine coverage.
We had a very large attendance of both new educators from all over the country
who come to the ASWE program to learn how to do research, what agencies are doing what.
I was very pleased to see that the new educators felt that it was a fine session.
They came down and told me so at the end of it.
I was also somewhat amused that a lot of the older
The research administrators felt like it was a good session, too.
They take advantage of those sorts of things, too.
I have a book here called 100 Years of Engineering at Texas A&M.
It was published in 1976 by C.W.
Crawford and others who contributed.
And this book says that the experiment station was established in 1914 to aid the industrial development of Texas.
Primarily, it started out as...
Dealing with road building, as you know, Texas has one of the best road systems in the country.
Also with water and sanitation.
What are, again, could you summarize some of the main points that the research and development staff is involved in today?
Some of the specific items.
Well, first of all, the first written word that I found on the history of this organization was in the catalog for 1914.

Dean Spence was the director at that time, and the written word at that time said that this engineering experiment station was established to parallel the agricultural experiment station, the agricultural experiment station having as a purpose to help solve problems of rural life,
The Engineering Experiment Station had its purpose to assist in solving the technical questions of urban life and questions of a special importance to Texas industries.
And the third part of its responsibility was to publish results of their research.
So it was not just to aid in the industrial development
of the state, but also to help cities solve their technical problems, and that we're doing today also.
Today's organization again includes researchers from all engineering departments.
It also has added a division with Prairie View A&M to help bring that school into the mainstream of engineering research and to assist them in developing their program.
We have a joint program now with the College of Business Administration.
That is a business engineering division.
I have an education and engineering division now with the College of Education.
We have a remote sensing center, which was established about 1968 as a consortium of colleges of engineering, science, geoscience, and agriculture.
We have the Nuclear Science Center, which has assisted over 60, 65 medical colleges and research laboratories and universities throughout the region.
We have also Industrial Economics Research Division, and we have a Strategic Technology Division that does defense-related work.
Incidentally, I might say that some of A&M's attributes are, I think, derived from its early military origin.
This university was not anti-defense work.
There was none of the rioting on the campus during the anti-Vietnam days.
We are not adverse to doing defense-related research, and we do do defense-related research.

We have research programs, either basic or applied, with the Army Research Office, the U.S. Air Force Office of Scientific Research, the Office of Naval Research, Department of Defense agencies throughout.
So I think our early
heritage has paid off in our research programs also.
How does the A&M research program rank compared to other institutions in the nation?
I haven't seen the latest but the latest that I did see we were ranked about 18th in the country.
This was a ranking by the National Science Foundation and that's pretty good standing.
Industrial support wise we do perhaps
more industrially sponsored research than most universities.
I think our ranking there was number four in the country and that's a relative sort of thing.
Would the dispute over the permanent university fund affect research programs?
The university fund
provides funds for building facilities, buildings, and helps a university grow in that way primarily.

And although the Engineering Experiment Station has been most successful in their engineering research program and have generated funds as a result of this contract research involvement and has been able to help pay for
buildings and research equipment.
The university fund provides even greater resources for the total university and hence helps the total university program, the university system program I think you perhaps need to say these days.
I'm from the old school so I think of Texas A&M as Texas A&M in all of its parts.
But today, there's more emphasis on the separate parts of the university system.
And the university itself is now a separate part and co-equal with the Ag Engineering Environment Station and Extension Services and that sort of thing.
I hope that this separation is not detrimental to the overall Texas A&M.
Because we need to maintain the attitude
We are Texas A&M, and we can help solve the nation's problems.
Let me ask you, Dr. Bain, about the $15 million in research funds that you have for this present year.
About what is the breakdown of where this money has come from?
Now, $15 million is not the total research program.
The total research program is more like $25 million.
The $15 million is total sponsored research.

In other words, that is research paid for by our customers, paid for by the sponsors who endorse and consider their problems of significant importance to the point of such significance that they're willing to pay for the research.
Could you tell us who some of these are?
Oh, yes.
NASA, this university does or this engineering experiment station does quite a bit of work for National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
We did quite a bit of work on the space shuttle and its wind tunnel testing.
We do quite a bit on lignite research sponsored by the Department of Energy and also by Texas Industries.
Petroleum companies are all acquiring coal and lignite resources, and we've been involved in ways to harness that energy from Texas resources.
Many, many industries, Exxon, Texaco, Phillips, Sun, Arco, Conoco, you name it, this university's involved.
What about state and federal funding?
State funding the engineering experiment station for this next biennium will be about five million.
Now for that five million, we create capabilities at Texas A&M to do creditable research.
We hire new faculty and new researchers and give them an opportunity
to do research and develop some credibility to demonstrate their capabilities and then help solve the real world's problems.
And we would expect that the $5 million would generate $20 million in sponsored research.
What about the other $5 million?
The other $5 million, we operate the data processing center, we operate a research and instrument shop,
the Nuclear Science Center, and all of these have budgets.
The other five million is in income to those organizations and for the operation of those facilities for the benefit of the entire university system.
Have you found that the state legislature has been
lenient or generous in funding the research program?
The state legislature has been very fair in their assessment of the benefits of engineering research at Texas A&M to the state and its economic development.
They've been very fair in their judgment.
They've not always given us what we ask for.
They always cut back to some extent and expect us to do better in our acquiring additional sponsored research.
And so far, with the very fine economic atmosphere in Texas and in the country, we've been able to do that.
And we've been able to continue a phenomenal growth.
One of our years that I recall,
Our statistics, we had a growth of 35% in sponsored research.
What year was that?
That was about 1975.
We've had 17%, 25%, 35% growth, those kinds of figures in one year.
And that's phenomenal.
It's almost the same kinds of growth that the enrollment at Texas A&M has experienced.
With an increase in enrollment, you have an increase in faculty requirements.
And when you increase faculty requirements, you also have
I need to pay those faculty, and we pay part of their salary for their research involvement.
And that allows departments to hire two people in place of one.
It helps develop the total program.
Can we pause here, please?
Sure.
